column1: 书名四不像（爱伦·坡经典幽默短篇小说）短简介这个城市到处都是奇观异景，国王竟是一只“长颈鹿”？“他”混在人群中，作诗高歌自己的伟大，遇到野兽攻击时飞奔在人群之首，臣民们都为他的奇装异服、诗歌才华和逃跑的机智勇猛高声喝彩。爱伦·坡幽默短篇小说《四不像》带领我们回到公元前的叙利亚安条克城，那里的国王和他的臣民合演了一出荒唐的闹剧。长简介幽默小说《四不像》中，两个现代人带我们回到公元前的叙利亚，参观安条克城。这座城市到处都是奇观异景。庆典上，国王把自己打扮成长颈鹿——简直就是四不像，还亲自作诗高歌自己的伟大，臣民们为他的装扮和歌声喝彩。当人声鼎沸时，平日里温顺的猛兽恢复兽性，扑向人群，当然也不放过“长颈鹿”。人们四下逃窜，跑在最前面的就是国王，他尖叫飞奔着平安地逃进了竞技场大门。人们再一次为他喝彩，赞美他的机智勇猛，并决定提前把奥林匹克的桂冠颁给他。小说标题源于《旧约·但以理书》，主人公也取材于圣经中的“暴君”安条克·伊皮法尼斯。作者通过对圣经故事的异类解读，用诙谐怪诞的笔法，讽刺统治者的丑恶用心以及民众的愚昧和盲目。关键字四不像；爱伦·坡；外研社编译组；国王；怪诞；反讽；作者（美）爱伦·坡作者简介爱伦·坡（1809—1849），19世纪美国诗人、小说家和文学评论家。侦探小说鼻祖、科幻小说先驱之一、恐怖小说大师、短篇哥特小说巅峰、象征主义先驱之一、唯美主义者。爱伦·坡一生穷愁潦倒，生前死后都受到外界褒贬不一的评价，其最著名的文艺理论是“效果论”。他和安布鲁斯·布尔斯、H. P. 洛夫克拉夫特并称为美国三大恐怖小说家。书评美国出了两个伟大的作家：爱伦·坡和马克·吐温。——萧伯纳

column1: His accession to the throne, or rather his usurpation of the sovereignty, a hundred and seventy-one years before the coming of Christ; his attempt to plunder the temple of Diana at Ephesus; his implacable hostility to the Jews; his pollution of the Holy of Holies; and his miserable death at Taba, after a tumultuous reign of eleven years, are circumstances of a prominent kind, and therefore more generally noticed by the historians of his time than the impious, dastardly, cruel, silly, and whimsical achievements which make up the sum total of his private life and reputation.
column2: 他在基督降世前171年继承王位，确切地说，是篡夺王权；他欲洗劫以弗所的狄安娜神庙的意图、他同犹太人势不两立的敌意、他对圣殿至圣所的亵渎以及他在动荡不安的11年统治后于塔巴的凄惨离世，这些都是令其名声大噪之事，他也因此备受同时代的历史学家们的关注，相比之下，构成他私生活和名声之和的那些邪恶的、卑鄙的、残酷的、愚蠢的以及荒唐的成就便被置之一旁了。

column1: Which may be thus paraphrased:
column2: 这首歌可以这样翻译：

column1: A thousand, a thousand, a thousand,
column2: 一千，一千，一千，

column1: A thousand, a thousand, a thousand,
column2: 一千，一千，一千，

column1: We, with one warrior, have slain!
column2: 仅剩一个，我们就要将敌人全灭！

column1: A thousand, a thousand, a thousand, a thousand.
column2: 一千，一千，一千，一千。

column1: Sing a thousand over again!
column2: 反复高唱千遍！

column1: Soho!—let us sing
column2: 嘿！——让我们一起高歌

column1: Long life to our king,
column2: 我们的国王万岁万岁万万岁，

column1: Who knocked over a thousand so fine!
column2: 他打倒了一千个敌人是如此了得！

column1: Soho!—let us roar,
column2: 嘿！——让我们一起高呼，

column1: He has given us more
column2: 他赐予我们

column1: Red gallons of gore
column2: 无数加仑的红色血水

column1: Than all Syria can furnish of wine!
column2: 比叙利亚能供应的酒水还要多上万千！

column1: “Do you hear that flourish of trumpets?”
column2: “你听到大肆鼓吹的号笛声了吗？”

column1: Yes: the king is coming!
column2: 是的：国王来了！

column1: See! the people are aghast with admiration, and lift up their eyes to the heavens in reverence.
column2: 快瞧！人们崇拜得都惊呆了，怀着敬畏之心举目望向天空。

column1: He comes;—he is coming;—there he is!
column2: 他来了；——他正朝这边走来；——他就在那里！

column1: “Who?—where?—the king?—do not behold him—cannot say that I perceive him.”
column2: “谁？——在哪里？——国王吗？——我看不见他——我怎么没看见他。”

column1: Then you must be blind.
column2: 那你一定是瞎了眼。

column1: “Very possible.
column2: “极有可能。

column1: Still I see nothing but a tumultuous mob of idiots and madmen, who are busy in prostrating themselves before a gigantic cameleopard, and endeavoring to obtain a kiss of the animal’s hoofs.
column2: 可我仍然只看见一大群聒噪的白痴和疯子，他们正忙着跪拜在一个巨大的长颈鹿跟前，拼命想在那个野兽的蹄子上献吻。

column1: See! the beast has very justly kicked one of the rabble over—and another—and another—and another.
column2: 看！那家伙还理所当然地挨个儿踢那些贱民——又一个——另一个——再一个。

column1: Indeed, I cannot help admiring the animal for the excellent use he is making of his feet.”
column2: 实话说来，我都忍不住感叹那野兽对自己蹄子的出色利用。”

column1: Rabble, indeed!—why these are the noble and free citizens of Epidaphne!
column2: 贱民，真的吗！——为什么偏偏他们就是高贵而自由的伊比达夫尼城的公民！

column1: Beasts, did you say?—take care that you are not overheard.
column2: 野兽们，怎么可能？——小心别被人听见。

column1: Do you not perceive that the animal has the visage of a man?
column2: 你没看见这动物有张人面吗？

column1: Why, my dear sir, that cameleopard is no other than Antiochus Epiphanes, Antiochus the Illustrious, King of Syria, and the most potent of all the autocrats of the East!
column2: 哎呀，我亲爱的朋友，那个长颈鹿就是安条克家族中的名人、叙利亚塞琉古王朝的国王、东方独裁者中最强势的安条克·伊皮法尼斯呀！

column1: It is true, that he is entitled, at times, Antiochus Epimanes—Antiochus the madman—but that is because all people have not the capacity to appreciate his merits.
column2: 的确，有时他也被称为安条克·伊皮蛮尼斯——疯子安条克——但那是因为还没有人有资格来评价他的功绩。

column1: It is also certain that he is at present ensconced in the hide of a beast, and is doing his best to play the part of a cameleopard; but this is done for the better sustaining his dignity as king.
column2: 毫无疑问，他现在正藏身于一张兽皮之下，且在竭力扮演好一只长颈鹿的角色；但这样做是为了更好地维护他作为国王的尊严。

column1: Besides, the monarch is of gigantic stature, and the dress is therefore neither unbecoming nor over large.
column2: 而且，国王身材魁梧，这身装束对他来说既不会太小也不会过大。

column1: We may, however, presume he would not have adopted it but for some occasion of especial state.
column2: 然而我们可以推测出他只会在某些特殊场合才会穿它。

column1: Such, you will allow, is the massacre of a thousand Jews.
column2: 你也会认同，现在就是一个屠杀了千名犹太人的特殊场合。

column1: With how superior a dignity the monarch perambulates on all fours!
column2: 国王如此匍匐巡行是多么威严高贵！

column1: His tail, you perceive, is held aloft by his two principal concubines, Elline and Argelais; and his whole appearance would be infinitely prepossessing, were it not for the protuberance of his eyes, which will certainly start out of his head, and the queer color of his face, which has become nondescript from the quantity of wine he has swallowed.
column2: 你看，他的尾巴被他的两位爱妾——艾琳娜和阿吉莱斯高举着。若不是那双快从脑袋上蹦出来的突起的青蛙眼和他脸上那因为饮酒过多而露出的不可言状的怪异色彩，他的整个打扮倒还挺讨人喜欢。

column1: Let us follow him to the hippodrome, whither he is proceeding, and listen to the song of triumph which he is commencing:
column2: 让我们尾随他去他正要前往的竞技场吧，也听听他正开唱的胜利之歌：

column1: Who is king but Epiphanes?
column2: 除了伊皮法尼斯谁能称王？

column1: Say—do you know?
column2: 说吧——你可知晓？

column1: Who is king but Epiphanes?
column2: 除了伊皮法尼斯谁能称王？

column1: Bravo!—bravo!
column2: 好极了！——棒极了！

column1: There is none but Epiphanes,
column2: 唯我伊皮法尼斯，

column1: No—there is none:
column2: 无人——再无人：

column1: So tear down the temples,
column2: 能如此拆毁这些神庙，

column1: And put out the sun!
column2: 熄灭那轮骄阳！

column1: Well and strenuously sung!
column2: 多么动听且激情的歌唱！

column1: The populace are hailing him ‘Prince of Poets,’ as well as ‘Glory of the East,’ ‘Delight of the Universe,’ and ‘Most Remarkable of Cameleopards.’
column2: 人群爆发出欢呼声，不仅称他为“东方之光”、“宇宙之福”和“最杰出的长颈鹿”，还尊他为“诗坛巨头”。

column1: They have encored his effusion, and do you hear?—he is singing it over again.
column2: 他们要求他再演唱一次，你听见了吗？——他又在唱那首歌了。

column1: When he arrives at the hippodrome, he will be crowned with the poetic wreath, in anticipation of his victory at the approaching Olympics.
column2: 当他到达竞技场时，他将被戴上诗人名号的花冠，以期待他在即将到来的奥林匹克竞赛上的胜利。

column1: “But, good Jupiter! what is the matter in the crowd behind us?”
column2: “但是，噢，天哪！我们身后这人群是怎么回事？”

column1: Behind us, did you say?—oh! ah!—I perceive.
column2: 你刚刚说，在我们身后吗？——哦！啊！——我注意到了。

column1: My friend, it is well that you spoke in time.
column2: 我的朋友，还好你说的正是时候。

column1: Let us get into a place of safety as soon as possible.
column2: 让我们尽快去个安全的地方。

column1: Here!—let us conceal ourselves in the arch of this aqueduct, and I will inform you presently of the origin of the commotion.
column2: 就是这里啦！——让我们藏到渡槽的拱形门下面去，我一会儿就告诉你这场骚乱的起因。

column1: It has turned out as I have been anticipating.
column2: 它和我一直以来所预想的一样。

column1: The singular appearance of the cameleopard and the head of a man, has, it seems, given offence to the notions of propriety entertained, in general, by the wild animals domesticated in the city.
column2: 看起来，是这长着人头的长颈鹿的怪异外表触犯了这座城市中驯养的野兽们一般能接受的礼节观念。

column1: A mutiny has been the result; and, as is usual upon such occasions, all human efforts will be of no avail in quelling the mob.
column2: 暴动就是其造成的结果。然而，通常在这种情况下，人为力量对镇压暴徒根本无济于事。

column1: Several of the Syrians have already been devoured; but the general voice of the four-footed patriots seems to be for eating up the cameleopard.
column2: 好几个叙利亚人已经被吞掉了，可那些四条腿的爱国者们的普遍呼声似乎是要把这头长颈鹿吃个精光。

column1: ‘The Prince of Poets,’ therefore, is upon his hinder legs, running for his life.
column2: 因此，“诗坛巨头”站立起来，正用后腿逃命。

column1: His courtiers have left him in the lurch, and his concubines have followed so excellent an example.
column2: 他的大臣们都弃他于危难之中，他的爱妾们也都纷纷追随大臣们树立的好榜样。

column1: ‘Delight of the Universe,’ thou art in a sad predicament!
column2: “宇宙之福”，你陷入了悲哀的窘境啊！

column1: ‘Glory of the East,’ thou art in danger of mastication!
column2: “东方之光”，你面临着被撕碎的危险！

column1: Therefore never regard so piteously thy tail; it will undoubtedly be draggled in the mud, and for this there is no help.
column2: 所以，绝对不要可怜巴巴地关心你那尾巴，它肯定会在泥垢里拖脏，但这也无可奈何。

column1: Look not behind thee, then, at its unavoidable degradation; but take courage, ply thy legs with vigor, and scud for the hippodrome!
column2: 那么，就不要回头看它那不可避免的落魄，而是鼓起勇气，奋力摆动双腿，全力飞奔向竞技场！

column1: Remember that thou art Antiochus Epiphanes.
column2: 记住你是安条克·伊皮法尼斯。

column1: Antiochus the Illustrious!—also ‘Prince of Poets,’ ‘Glory of the East,’ ‘Delight of the Universe,’ and ‘Most Remarkable of Cameleopards!’
column2: 杰出的安条克！——也是“诗坛巨头”、“东方之光”、“宇宙之福”和“最杰出的长颈鹿”！

column1: Heavens! what a power of speed thou art displaying!
column2: 天哪！你所展示的速度能力是多么强大！

column1: What a capacity for leg-bail thou art developing!
column2: 你所显露的逃跑能力又是多么惊人！

column1: Run, Prince!—Bravo, Epiphanes!
column2: 跑呀，巨头！——棒极了，伊皮法尼斯！

column1: Well done, Cameleopard!—Glorious Antiochus!—He runs!—he leaps!—he flies!
column2: 做得好，长颈鹿！——享誉盛名的安条克！——他跑！——他跳！——他飞！

column1: Like an arrow from a catapult he approaches the hippodrome!
column2: 他如离弦之箭一般冲到了竞技场！

column1: He leaps!—he shrieks!—he is there!
column2: 他飞跃！——他尖叫！——他到了！

column1: This is well; for hadst thou, ‘Glory of the East,’ been half a second longer in reaching the gates of the Amphitheatre, there is not a bear’s cub in Epidaphne that would not have had a nibble at thy carcase.
column2: 可是，“东方之光”，你若是到达竞技场大门时迟了半秒，伊皮达夫尼城的每一只幼熊都将细细啃咬你的尸体。

column1: Let us be off—let us take our departure!—for we shall find our delicate modern ears unable to endure the vast uproar which is about to commence in celebration of the king’s escape!
column2: 我们该离开了——我们出发吧！——因为我们将会发现，我们那脆弱的现代化耳朵将无法忍受即将开始的庆祝国王逃脱的巨大欢呼声。

column1: Listen! it has already commenced.
column2: 听哪！那声音已经开始了。

column1: See!—the whole town is topsy-turvy.
column2: 看哪！——整座城市都乱七八糟。

column1: “Surely this is the most populous city of the East!
column2: “这无疑是东方人口最多的城市！

column1: What a wilderness of people! what a jumble of all ranks and ages! what a multiplicity of sects and nations! what a variety of costumes! what a Babel of languages! what a screaming of beasts! what a tinkling of instruments! what a parcel of philosophers!”
column2: 多么浩瀚的茫茫人海！男女老少和社会各阶级的人都乱成一团！如此多样的教派和种族！五花八门的衣装打扮！混乱繁杂的南腔北调！尖锐刺耳的野兽嘶吼！叮当作响的乐器声！还有一群扎堆的哲学家！

column1: Come let us be off.
column2: 来吧，我们走吧。

column1: “Stay a moment!
column2: “等一会儿！

column1: I see a vast hubbub in the hippodrome; what is the meaning of it, I beseech you?”
column2: 我看见竞技场内一阵大骚动；请你告诉我，究竟发生了什么事？”

column1: That?—oh, nothing!
column2: 那阵骚动？——哦，没什么！

column1: The noble and free citizens of Epidaphne being, as they declare, well satisfied of the faith, valor, wisdom, and divinity of their king, and having, moreover, been eye-witnesses of his late superhuman agility, do think it no more than their duty to invest his brows (in addition to the poetic crown) with the wreath of victory in the footrace—a wreath which it is evident he must obtain at the celebration of the next Olympiad, and which, therefore, they now give him in advance.
column2: 就如伊皮达夫尼城那高贵自由的公民们所宣布的一样，他们对他们国王的忠诚、勇猛、智慧和神威一直深信不疑。此外，他们又刚亲眼见证他宛如超人般的敏捷身手，认为他们的职责就是授予他（除诗人桂冠之外）赛跑比赛的胜利花环——一个显然在下届奥林匹克竞赛的庆典上他会获得的花环，现在他们提前颁给了他。

column1: [1]Flavius Vospicus says, that the hymn here introduced was sung by the rabble upon the occasion of Aurelian, in the Sarmatic war, having slain, with his own hand, nine hundred and fifty of the enemy.
column2: ［1］弗拉维奥·沃斯皮库斯说，这首赞歌是在萨尔马提亚战争中奥勒良亲手杀死了九百五十名敌人后由贱民们所唱。
